channel.title: Jessica Jagdeo ESM 244 Blog
channel.description: Recent content on Jessica Jagdeo ESM 244 Blog

item.title: Go is for lovers
item.description: Hugo uses the excellent go html/template library for its template engine. It is an extremely lightweight engine that provides a very small amount of logic. In our experience that it is just the right amount of logic to be able to create a good static website. If you have used other template systems from different languages or frameworks you will find a lot of similarities in go templates. This document is a brief primer on using go templates.

item.title: Hugo is for lovers
item.description: Step 1. Install Hugo Goto hugo releases and download the appropriate version for your os and architecture. Save it somewhere specific as we will be using it in the next step. More complete instructions are available at installing hugo Step 2. Build the Docs Hugo has its own example site which happens to also be the documentation site you are reading right now. Follow the following steps: Clone the hugo repository Go into the repo Run hugo in server mode and build the docs Open your browser to http://localhost:1313 Corresponding pseudo commands:

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: Creating a new theme
item.description: Introduction This tutorial will show you how to create a simple theme in Hugo. I assume that you are familiar with HTML, the bash command line, and that you are comfortable using Markdown to format content. I'll explain how Hugo uses templates and how you can organize your templates to create a theme. I won't cover using CSS to style your theme. We'll start with creating a new site with a very basic template.

item.title: Assessment of Santa Ynez River Water Quality
item.description: Santa Ynez Water Quality Historical Data Data only goes back to 1998 Turbidity units: NTU TSS and TDS units: mg/L santa_ynez_water_quality_raw <- read_csv("RAW_santa_ynez_water_quality.csv") santa_ynez_water_quality <- santa_ynez_water_quality_raw %>% select(OrganizationFormalName, ActivityStartDate, MonitoringLocationIdentifier, CharacteristicName, ResultSampleFractionText, ResultMeasureValue, "ResultMeasure/MeasureUnitCode") %>% # Selecting only relevant columns filter(CharacteristicName == "Total dissolved solids"| CharacteristicName == "Turbidity" | CharacteristicName == "Total suspended solids") %>% separate(ActivityStartDate, sep = "-", into = c("year", "month", "day")) %>% group_by(year, month, CharacteristicName) %>% summarize(value = sum(ResultMeasureValue)) santa_ynez_water_quality$date <- as.

item.title: Bonanza Creek Snowshow Hare Examination
item.description: From 1999 to 2017, physical characteristics of snowshoe hares were observed and recorded in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest within Alaska (Kielland et al. 2017). This project utilizes the data obtained from this study to visualize the weight and sex of the observed snowshoe hares. In addition, this project explores the summary statistics of the recorded weights for both female and male snowshoe hares.

item.title: Examining Runoff Ratio in Santa Cruz Creek Sub-basin
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(readxl) library(lubridate) library(janitor) library(ggthemes) library(zoo) library(magrittr) library(gghighlight) library(tsibble) library(paletteer) Santa Cruz Gauge Observed Flow # Read in SC observed flow data sc_usgs_flow <- read_csv("sc_creek_clean.csv") sc_usgs_flow$dis_cfs <- as.numeric(as.character(sc_usgs_flow$dis_cfs)) # Convert date from character to date sc_usgs_flow$date <- as.Date(sc_usgs_flow$date, "%m/%d/%Y") # Create column for daily inflow in cumecs (cfs to cubic meters per second (cumecs)) sc_flow_cumecs <- sc_usgs_flow %>% mutate(dis_cumecs = (dis_cfs*0.03)) %>% select(date, dis_cumecs) Surface runoff calculation Divide aggregated monthly discharge by area (km) to obtain to meters of runoff.

item.title: Gibraltar Reservoir Capacity
item.description: # Load in necessary packages library(tidyverse) library(readxl) library(janitor) library(lubridate) library(gghighlight) library(kableExtra) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) library(here) # Load in the data and clean gibraltar_storage <- read_excel("RAW_Gibraltar_Storage_Elevation_2001_2019.xls") %>% rename("date" = "36892", "capacity" = "3182", "total_capacity" = "7500") %>% mutate(capacity_m3 = (capacity*1233.48)) Water storage in Gibraltar Reservoir gibraltar_cap_plot <- ggplot(gibraltar_storage, aes(x = date, y = capacity)) + geom_area(color = "darkblue", fill = "darkblue") + # creates area rather than bars theme_classic() + labs(x = "Year", y = "Water (acre-feet)" ) + ggtitle("Gibraltar Water Stored (2001 - 2018)\n") + theme(plot.

item.title: Migrate from Jekyll
item.description: Move static content to static Jekyll has a rule that any directory not starting with _ will be copied as-is to the _site output. Hugo keeps all static content under static. You should therefore move it all there. With Jekyll, something that looked like ▾ <root>/ ▾ images/ logo.png should become ▾ <root>/ ▾ static/ ▾ images/ logo.png Additionally, you'll want any files that should reside at the root (such as CNAME) to be moved to static.
